text: Abu Abdillah Muhammad ibn Yazid ibn Majah (), commonly called Ibn Majah was a Persian, hadith scholar.Frye, ed. by R.N. (1975). The Cambridge history of Iran (Repr. ed.). London: Cambridge U.P. p. 471. ISBN 978-0-521-20093-6. His hadith collection Sunan ibn Majah is one of the six major hadith collections.Ludwig W. Adamec (2009), Historical Dictionary of Islam, p.139. Scarecrow Press. ISBN 0810861615. == Biography == Ibn Majah was born in Qazwin, the modern-day Iranian province of Qazvin, in 824 CE. Majah was the nickname of his father, and not that of his grandfather. Al-Dhahabi mentioned following of Ibn Majah's works: * Sunan Ibn Majah: one of the six major collections of hadith * Kitab al-Tafsir: a book of Quran explanation * Kitab al-Tarikh: a book of history or, more likely, a listing of hadith tellers. == References == Category:History of Islam Category:Hadith scholars Category:820s births Category:880s deaths
